The allusion is to the dregs of the populace, the inhabitants of the lower portions of the city near the river, and their coarse witticisms upon the emperors Õæ comp. ad Nat. i. 17, ‚Äò vani- tatis sacrilegia conveniam, et ipsius vernaculae gentis irreverentiam recognoscam, et festivos libellos quos statuae sciunt, et illa obliqua nonnunquam dicta a concilio atque maledicta quae circi sonant. Si non armis saltem lingua semper 'rebelles estis.' Lampoons upon the emperors were infractions of the law of majestas as enforced by Au- gustus, and Tiberius made even abusive language treasonable.
